On 28 March 2017 the [[United States House of Representatives]] passed a resolution of disapproval ([https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/senate-joint-resolution/34 S.J.Res 34]) to overturn the Broadband Consumer Privacy Proposal [[privacy law]] by the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) and is now expected to be approved by [[United States' President]] [[Donald Trump]].<ref name=wash1/><ref name="vox1">{{cite web|title=What the Republican online privacy bill means for you|url=https://www.vox.com/new-money/2017/3/29/15107110/republican-isp-data-privacy|website=Vox|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref><ref name="guard1"/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Schultz|first1=Marisa|title=Trump likely to sign bill allowing ISPs to sell your browsing data|url=https://nypost.com/2017/03/28/internet-providers-closer-to-selling-customers-private-info/|publisher=New York Post|accessdate=29 March 2017|date=29 March 2017}}</ref> It was passed with 215 [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] votes against 205 votes of disapproval.
The repealed privacy protections approved in 2016 sought to regulate what companies can do with data of customers' browsing habits, communication contents, app usage history, [[location data]] and social security numbers and safeguard customer data against [[Security hacker|hackers]] and thieves.<ref name=wash1>{{cite web|title=The House just voted to wipe away the FCC’s landmark Internet privacy protections|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2017/03/28/the-house-just-voted-to-wipe-out-the-fccs-landmark-internet-privacy-protections/|website=Washington Post|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref>
Supporters of the vote argue that the privacy regulations stifle [[innovation]] by forcing Internet providers to abide by unreasonably strict guidelines.<ref name=wash1/>
Due to the repealment [[Internet service provider]]s (ISP) like [[Comcast]], [[AT&T]] and [[Verizon]] may sell [[Web browsing history|Web browsing histories]] and other sensitive data directly to marketers, financial firms and other companies without consumers' consent. Furthermore, the FCC will be forbidden from issuing similar rules in the future.<ref name=wash1/>
==Background== {{Main|Surveillance capitalism}} Internet providers have historically generated their revenue from selling [[Internet access|access to the Internet]] and are now looking to increase their revenue by tapping the data their customers generate as they make use of the Internet.<ref name=wash1/>{{Additional citation needed|date=March 2017}}
The industry with its [[profit motive]] favors an interpretation of privacy that does not consider browsing history or app usage data to be sensitive and protected — the Federal Trade Commission's (FTC) interpretation.<ref name=wash1/> However the FTC is unable to enforce its own guidelines without new authority from [[United States Congress|Congress]].<ref name=wash1/>
On 16 March 2017 [[CTIA – The Wireless Association|CTIA]] claims that "Web browsing and app usage history are not 'sensitive information'" in a filing with the FCC.<ref name="arst5">{{cite web|title=ISPs say your Web browsing and app usage history isn’t "sensitive"|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/03/isps-say-your-web-browsing-and-app-usage-history-isnt-sensitive/|publisher=Ars Technica|accessdate=29 March 2017|language=en-us}}</ref>
==History== * On 27 October the FCC imposed new privacy rules that were scheduled to take effect by the end of 2017 that would have required ISPs to get opt-in consent from consumers before sharing Web browsing data and other private information with advertisers and other third parties<ref name="arst4">{{cite web|title=FCC imposes ISP privacy rules and takes aim at mandatory arbitration|url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2016/10/isps-will-soon-have-to-ask-you-before-sharing-private-data-with-advertisers/|website=Ars Technica|accessdate=29 March 2017|language=en-us}}</ref> The FCC final rules were titled "Protecting the Privacy of Customers of Broadband and Other Telecommunication Services," 81 Fed. Reg. 87274 (December 2, 2016).<ref name="whiteh1">{{cite web|title=S.J.Res. 34 – Disapproving the Federal Communications Commission’s Rule on Privacy of Customers of Broadband Services|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/03/28/statement-administration-policy-sjres-34-%E2%80%93-disapproving-federal|website=whitehouse.gov|accessdate=29 March 2017|language=en|date=28 March 2017}}</ref> * On 15 February 2017 Senator [[Jeff Flake]] confirmed that he plans to introduce a resolution that would roll back the FCC's broadband privacy rules via the [[Congressional Review Act]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Flake to use CRA in bid to undo FCC broadband privacy rules|url=https://secure.politico.com/tipsheets/morning-tech/2017/02/flake-working-on-cra-to-undo-fcc-broadband-privacy-rules-218757|publisher=POLITICO|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> * On 7 March 2017 Senator Jeff Flake and 23 Republican co-sponsors introduced the resolution.<ref name="arst3">{{cite web|title=GOP senators’ new bill would let ISPs sell your Web browsing data|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/03/gop-senators-new-bill-would-let-isps-sell-your-web-browsing-data/|website=Ars Technica|accessdate=29 March 2017|language=en-us}}</ref> * <!--In the 2 days -->From 21 March to the resolution's passage more than 15,000 calls against the measure were made into the Capitol.<ref name=yuba1>{{cite web|title=House Republicans Vote to Destroy FCC’s Online Privacy Protections|url=https://yubanet.com/usa/house-republicans-vote-to-destroy-fccs-online-privacy-protections/|website=yubanet.com|accessdate=29 March 2017}}</ref> * On 22 March 2017 advocacy groups including [[Free Press (organization)|Free Press]], [[Demand Progress]], and the [[ACLU]] went to Congress to deliver nearly 90.000 petitions to "save broadband privacy".<ref name="arst2"/> * On 23 March 2017 the United States' [[Senate]] passes the resolution with the votes of 50 Republicans against 48.<ref name=arst1>{{cite web|title=How ISPs can sell your Web history—and how to stop them|url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2017/03/how-isps-can-sell-your-web-history-and-how-to-stop-them/|website=Ars Technica|accessdate=29 March 2017|language=en-us}}</ref><ref name="arst2"/> * On 28 March 2017 the United States' House of Representatives passes resolution "S.J.Res 34" * On 28 March 2017 the [[White House]] releases a statement according to which the administration strongly supports House passage of S.J.Res. 34 and the President's advisors would recommend that he sign the bill into law.<ref name="whiteh1"/>
==Reception== Many of the privacy advocates who oppose ISP data sharing also oppose tracking by ad networks and technology companies such as [[Google]] but find ISP tracking extra worrisome as ISPs have access to all of one's browsing data − not just data from specific sites that share their data with particular ad networks, and as disabling cookies or [[adblocker]]s can't prevent this sort of tracking.<ref name="vox1"/>
Jeffrey Chester, executive director of the Center for Digital Democracy states that the vote means that "Americans will never be safe online from having their most personal details stealthily scrutinized and sold to the highest bidder".<ref name=wash1/>
Senator [[Brian Schatz]] states that "if this [resolution] is passed, neither the FCC nor the FTC will have clear authority when it comes to how Internet service providers protect consumers' data privacy and security. Regardless of politics, allowing ISPs to operate in a rule-free zone without any government oversight is reckless".<ref name="arst3"/>
According to [[Anna Eshoo]] the consequences of the resolution's passage are clear: "broadband providers like AT&T, Comcast, and others will be able to sell your personal information to the highest bidder without your permission".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kastrenakes|first1=Jacob|title=Congress just cleared the way for internet providers to sell your web browsing history|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/03/28/congress-clears-way-for-isps-to-sell-browsing-history.html|website=CNBC|accessdate=29 March 2017|date=28 March 2017}}</ref>
[[Michael Copps]], a former member of the Federal Communications Commission, called the bill a "perversion of what the internet was supposed to be".<ref name="vox1"/>
[[Dallas Harris]], an attorney who specializes in broadband privacy and a policy fellow at consumer advocacy group [[Public Knowledge]] notes that ISPs might be able to figure out where you bank, your political views, and your sexual orientation based on what sites you visit and asserts that "the level of information that they can figure out is beyond what even most customers expect". Various information can be extracted from Internet traffic − for instance "the fact that you're looking at a website can reveal when you're home, when you're not home" and according to her "you don't need to see the contents of every communication to develop efficient [[ad tracking]] mechanisms".<ref name=arst1/>
Senator [[Ed Markey]] states that "President Trump may be outraged by fake violations of his own privacy, but every American should be alarmed by the very real violation of privacy that will result [from] the Republican roll-back of broadband privacy protections".<ref name="arst2">{{cite web|title=Senate votes to let ISPs sell your Web browsing history to advertisers|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/03/senate-votes-to-let-isps-sell-your-web-browsing-history-to-advertisers/|website=Ars Technica|accessdate=29 March 2017|language=en-us}}</ref>
Cable lobby group [[National Cable & Telecommunications Association|NCTA]] says that they "appreciate today's Senate action to repeal unwarranted FCC rules that deny consumers consistent privacy protection online and violate competitive neutrality".<ref name="arst2"/>
[[Michael Capuano]] asks "What the heck are you thinking? What is in your mind? Why would you want to give out any of our personal information to a faceless corporation for the sole purpose of them selling it?".<ref>{{cite web|title=Senate votes to let ISPs sell your browsing data|url=http://www.wflx.com/story/35019359/senate-votes-to-let-isps-sell-your-browsing-data|accessdate=29 March 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Lofholm|first1=Andrew|title=Internet providers likely allowed to sell personal browser data without user's consent|url=http://www.wptv.com/news/region-c-palm-beach-county/west-palm-beach/internet-providers-likely-allowed-to-sell-personal-browser-data-without-users-consent|publisher=WPTV|accessdate=29 March 2017|date=29 March 2017}}</ref>
[[Evan Greer]], campaign director of digital rights group [[Fight for the Future]] states that "today Congress proved once again that they care more about the wishes of the corporations that fund their campaigns than they do about the safety and security of their constituents". She also states that:<ref name="guard1">{{cite web|last1=Solon|first1=Olivia|title=Trump poised to sign away privacy protections for internet users|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/mar/28/privacy-protection-sell-web-browsing-history-data|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=29 March 2017|date=29 March 2017}}</ref>
{{quote|Gutting these privacy rules won’t just allow internet service providers to spy on us and sell our personal information, it will also enable more unconstitutional mass government surveillance, and fundamentally undermine our cybersecurity by making our sensitive personal information vulnerable to hackers, identity thieves, and foreign governments}}
[[Craig Aaron]], Free Press Action Fund President and CEO writes in a statement:<ref name=yuba1/>
{{quote|Ignoring calls from thousands of their constituents, House Republicans just joined their colleagues in the Senate in violating internet users’ privacy rights. Apparently they see no problem with cable and phone companies snooping on your private medical and financial information, your religious activities or your sex life. They voted to take away the privacy rights of hundreds of millions of Americans just so a few giant companies could pad their already considerable profits. Facing a growing public outcry, they rushed through this vote before more people could find out what was at stake.}}
SearchInternetHistory.com is a [[crowdfunding]] campaign trying to raise $1 million to buy the browsing history of Republican officeholders like Senate Majority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]], Speaker [[Paul Ryan]], and FCC Chair [[Ajit Pai]].<ref name="vox1"/>
==Management== Consumers may switch to ISPs with better privacy protections. However this could be difficult for some as many Americans only have a choice of one or two broadband companies in their area according to federal statistics.<ref name=wash1/> Senator [[Ron Wyden]] states that thus their only choice may be between "giving up their browsing history for an Internet provider to sell to the highest bidder or having no Internet at all".<ref name="arst2"/> Furthermore, the existence of such ISPs is not guaranteed and Jeremy Gillula, a senior staff technologist at the Electronic Frontier Foundation notes that it's "unclear if they would even have to tell you they were doing it".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Estes|first1=Adam Clark|title=How to Hide Your Browsing History From Your Snooping ISP|url=https://gizmodo.com/how-to-hide-your-browsing-history-from-your-snooping-is-1793687193|website=Gizmodo|accessdate=29 March 2017|date=29 March 2017}}</ref>
[[VPN]] can be used to protect ones data from ISPs<ref name="vox1"/><ref name=arst1/><ref name="verge1">{{cite web|title=A VPN can stop internet companies from selling your data — but it’s not a magic bullet|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/3/25/15056290/vpn-isp-internet-privacy-security-fcc-repeal|publisher=The Verge|accessdate=29 March 2017|date=25 March 2017|author=Adi Robertson}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Thomson|first1=Iain|title=So my ISP can now sell my browsing history – what can I do?|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2017/03/28/so_my_isp_can_now_sell_my_browsing_history_what_can_i_do/|accessdate=29 March 2017|date=28 March 2017}}</ref> or theoretically to subscribe to foreign ISPs with better privacy protections.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} However good VPNs generally cost money, take some effort and minor technical skills to set up, and will slightly degrade the connection speed.<ref name="vox1"/>
Furthermore, the [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor browser]] can be used to surf [[Internet anonymity|anonymously]]. This would however significantly slow down connection speed and not be adequate in most cases.<ref name=arst1/><ref name=kcra1/><ref name="verge1"/>
Also ISPs can't look into the encrypted traffic of sites that use [[Transport Layer Security|TLS]] whose URLs starts with "[[HTTPS]]" but only the [[domain name]].<ref name=arst1/><ref name="verge1"/> The [[HTTPS Everywhere]] browser extension allows for better protection via HTTPS.<ref name=arst1/><ref>{{cite web|last1=McCarthy|first1=Kieren|title=Your internet history on sale to highest bidder: US Congress votes to shred ISP privacy rules|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2017/03/28/congress_approves_sale_of_internet_histories/|accessdate=29 March 2017|date=28 March 2017}}</ref> Also apps that use [[end-to-end encryption]] can be used to protect communication contents.<ref name="verge1"/>
Some consumers might assume that they can protect their browsing histories by deleting them<ref name="vox1"/> or by using privacy modes of browsers such as [[Google Chrome|Chrome]]'s "incognito mode" which is not the case.<ref name=kcra1>{{cite web|last1=Iqbal|first1=Maneeza|title=Here's how you can still protect your web history from marketers|url=http://www.kcra.com/article/heres-how-you-can-still-protect-your-web-history-from-marketers/9200362|website=KCRA|accessdate=29 March 2017|language=en|date=29 March 2017}}</ref><ref name=arst1/>
==See also== {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Data Protection Directive]] (EU) * [[Mass surveillance]] * [[Hawthorne effect]] * [[Targeted advertising]] * [[Internet pornography]] * [[Internet privacy]] * [[Data security]] * [[Data breach]] * [[List of data breaches]] * [[Raw capitalism]] * [[Surveillance capitalism]] }}

{{legend|#008000|Parties}} {{legend|#00ff00|Observers negotiating accession}} {{legend|#ff8040|Observers only}}]] The '''Agreement on Government Procurement''' ('''GPA''') is a [[plurilateral agreement]] under the auspices of the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO) that entered into force in 1981. It was then renegotiated in parallel with the [[Uruguay Round]] in 1994, and entered into force on 1 January 1996. The agreement was subsequently revised on 30 March 2012. The revised GPA came into effect on 6 July 2014. It regulates the [[government procurement]] of goods and services by the public authorities of the parties to the agreement, based on the principles of openness, transparency and non-discrimination. {{-}} ==Parties== The following WTO Members are parties to the agreement:{{cite web|url=http://www.wto.org/english/tratop_e/gproc_e/memobs_e.htm#parties|title=Parties and observers to the GPA|publisher=WTO|accessdate=9 June 2016}} {| class="wikitable !style="width: 50%;"| Parties !| Accession date |- | Canada || 1 January 1996 |- | The [[European Union]] with respect to Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxemburg, the Netherlands, Portugal, Spain, Sweden and the United Kingdom || 1 January 1996 |- | Israel || 1 January 1996 |- | Japan || 1 January 1996 |- | Norway || 1 January 1996 |- | Switzerland || 1 January 1996 |- | United States || 1 January 1996 |- | The Netherlands with respect to [[Aruba]] || 25 October 1996 |- | with an asterisk (*) negotiating accession: Albania*, Argentina, Australia*, Bahrain, Cameroon, Chile, China*, Colombia, Costa Rica, Georgia*, India, Indonesia, Jordan*, Kyrgyz Republic*, Macedonia, Malaysia, Mongolia, Oman*, Pakistan, Panama, Russian Federation, Saudi Arabia, Seychelles, Sri Lanka, Tajikistan*, Thailand, Turkey and Vietnam. ==History== ===European Union=== In 2016, several commentators{{Who|date=November 2018}} suggested that following the [[Brexit|United Kingdom's departure from the European Union (EU)]] the UK would need to renegotiate to become a party to the GPA in its own right - as the UK's membership was by virtue of being a member of the EU.e.g. Cameron, A., [https://andersonstrathern.co.uk/news-insight/eu-referendum-public-procurement-law/ Brexit: What does it mean for public procurement?], 8 July 2016, accessed 11 September 2016 In 2018, ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]'' reported that some WTO members, including [[Moldova]], may block the UK's post-Brexit membership of the GPA or request concessions.https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-11-02/brexit-talks-over-security-deal-said-to-leave-brits-frustrated ==References== {{reflist}} == The '''Antiquities and Monuments Ordinance''', in [[Hong Kong Law]] (Cap. 53), was enacted in 1976 to preserve the objects of historical, archaeological and palaeontological interest and for matters ancillary thereto or connected therewith. It is administered by the [[Secretary for Home Affairs]] ([[Antiquities and Monuments Office]] of [[Leisure and Cultural Services Department]]).
==Antiquities== Under the Ordinance, "Antiquities" are defined as "places, buildings, sites or structures erected, formed or built by human agency before the year 1800 and the ruins or remains of any such place, building, site or structure, whether or not the same has been modified, added to or restored after the year 1799" and "relics". The word, "relics" is defined as the movable objects made, shaped, painted, carved, inscribed, created, manufactured, produced or modified by human agency before the year 1800 or those have not been modified, added to or restored after the year 1799. Fossil remains or impressions are also considered as "relics" under the Ordinance.
===Archaeological sites=== All archaeological relics in Hong Kong are considered as properties of [[Government of Hong Kong|the Government]] under the Ordinance. This includes ancient architecture, kilns, hearths, rock carvings, farm lands, shell or refuse mounds and foot prints of ancient human beings.
The Antiquities Authority is empowered to regulate the search and excavation of all such relics through a system of licensing.
The most important sites are declared as [[Declared monuments of Hong Kong|Declared Monuments]]. These are defined under the Ordinance as any feature, structure, building and artefact which are considered important because of its historical, archaeological or palaeontological significance.
Over 180 sites are known as Sites of Specific Archaeological Interest (SSAI).
==Monuments== After consultation with the Board and with the approval of the [[Chief Executive of Hong Kong|Chief Executive]], the [[Secretary for Development]] may, by notice in the Gazette, declare any place, building, site or structure, which he or she considers to be of public interest by reason of its historical, archaeological or palaeontological significance, to be [[Declared monuments of Hong Kong|a monument]].
According to the Ordinance, any one without permits granted by the Secretary for Home Affairs, is not allowed to excavate, carry on building or other works, plant or fell trees or deposit earth or refuse on or in any proposed monuments or monuments; or demolish, remove, obstruct, deface or interfere with any proposed monuments or monuments.
===Proposed monuments=== {{main|Proposed monuments (Hong Kong)}} Several historical building have been declared as proposed monuments for temporary statutory protection within a specified period.<ref name="Subcommittee on Antiquities and Monuments (Declaration of Proposed Monument)(Ho Tung Gardens) Notice">[http://www.legco.gov.hk/yr10-11/english/hc/sub_leg/sc08/papers/sc080223cb1-1478-1-e.pdf Subcommittee on Antiquities and Monuments(Declaration of Proposed Monument)(Ho Tung Gardens) Notice:Response to Members’ request for information made at the meeting held on 23 February 2011]</ref><ref name="AMO">[http://amo.gov.hk/en/news_20080125a.php Government to declare King Yin Lei and Maryknoll Convent School monuments]</ref>
[[King Yin Lei]], now being declared monument, was declared a "proposed monument" on September 15, 2007 due to the damage caused by the non-structural works. [[Jessville]], now a Grade III historical building, was declared a "proposed monument" on April 20, 2007.<ref name="AMO"/>
==See also== * [[Heritage conservation in Hong Kong]] * [[Declared monuments of Hong Kong]]

{{Infobox Politician | name = Bill Hartley | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{birthdate|1916|12|12}} | birth_place = [[Estevan]], [[Saskatchewan]] | death_date = {{deathdateandage|2003|5|4|1916|12|12}} | residence = | constituency_AM1 = [[Yale-Lillooet]]
[[Yale (provincial electoral district)|Yale]] (1963-1966) | assembly1 = British Columbia Legislative | term_start1 = September 30, 1963 | term_end1 = December 11, 1975 | predecessor1 = [[Irvine Finlay Corbett|Irvine Corbett]] | successor1 = [[Thomas Waterland]] | party = [[British Columbia New Democratic Party|New Democrat]] | religion = | profession = Insurance agent | spouse = | children = }} '''William Leonard Hartley''' (December 12, 1916 – May 4, 2003) was an electrician, insurance salesman and political figure in [[British Columbia]]. He represented [[Yale (provincial electoral district)|Yale]] from 1963 to 1966 and [[Yale-Lillooet]] from 1966 to 1975 as a [[British Columbia New Democratic Party|New Democrat]]. He was born in [[Estevan]], [[Saskatchewan]], the son of Leonard Hartley and Sarah Ann Lee, both natives of [[England]],{{cite book |title=Canadian Parliamentary Guide, 1965 |last=Normandin |first=P G |year=1965}} and grew up in [[Clayburn, British Columbia]]. Hartley settled in Mission, B.C. He was president of the North Fraser Co-operative Association and served on the board of C.U. & C. Health Services.{{cite book |title=Growth of the N.D.P. in B.C., 1900-1970: 81 political biographies |last=Webster |first=Daisy |year=1970}} Hartley ran unsuccessfully a number of times as a Co-operative Commonwealth Federation candidate for a seat in federal elections, before he was elected provincially for the New Democratic Party in 1963. He was subsequently re-elected three times. He served in the provincial cabinet as Minister of Public Works, in the New Democratic Party government from 1972-75{{cite web |url=http://www.leg.bc.ca/Hansard/hansindx/30th5th/names.htm |title=5th Session, 30th Parliament |publisher=Legislative Assembly of British Columbia |accessdate=2011-12-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110128092449/http://leg.bc.ca/hansard/hansindx/30th5th/names.htm |archivedate=2011-01-28 |df= }} Hartley was defeated when he ran for re-election in 1975.{{cite web |url=http://www.elections.bc.ca/docs/rpt/1871-1986_ElectoralHistoryofBC.pdf |title=Electoral History of British Columbia, 1871-1986 |publisher=Elections BC |accessdate=2011-07-27}} He retired from the insurance business in 1986.{{cite web |url=http://www.hartleyinsurance.com/all-about-hartley-insurance |title=All About Hartley Insurance |publisher=Bill Hartley Insurance |accessdate=2011-12-28}} Hartley help found Co-op Fire and Casualty, later [[The Co-operators]]. In 1955, he married Marianne Martha Mueller a nurse from Lumsden, Saskatchewan. He had three children, Gretchen, Eric and Lisa. == References == {{reflist}} {{Barrett Ministry}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hartley, William L}} [[Category:1916 births]] [[Category:2003 deaths]] [[Category:British Columbia New Democratic Party MLAs]] [[Category:Electricians]] [[Category:Insurance agents]] [[Category:Members of the Executive Council of British Columbia]] [[Category:People from Estevan]] {{BritishColumbia-politician-stub}}

Thrasher
Bryan Eustis Wagner
Leslie Helen Wagner | parents=Wiltz W., Sr., and Helen Bell Wagner | footnotes= }} '''James Bryan Wagner''', known as '''Bryan Wagner''' (March 2, 1943 – July 29, 2018), was the first [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] since [[Reconstruction era of the United States|Reconstruction]] to have been elected to the [[New Orleans City Council]]. He filled a vacancy of an unexpired term in District A from May 1980 to April 1982 and a full term until 1986.{{cite web|url=http://nutrias.org/facts/council.htm|title=New Orleans City Council members since 1954|publisher=nutrias.org|accessdate=February 17, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://obits.nola.com/obituaries/nola/obituary.aspx?n=j-bryan-wagner&pid=189782010|title=J. Bryan Wagner's obituary|publisher=''[[New Orleans Times-Picayune]]''|date=August 3, 2018}} ==Background== Wagner was the younger of two sons of the late Wiltz W. Wagner, Sr., and Helen Bell Wagner (c. 1913–2004), who taught [[English language|English]] at the [[University of New Orleans]]. Helen Wagner graduated from [[H. Sophie Newcomb Memorial College]] and [[Tulane University]]. She represented Louisiana as the "Acadian Girl" at the Paris World Exposition of 1931. A parishioner of the [[Episcopalian]] Christ Church Cathedral in New Orleans, she also served on the [[vestry]] and altar guild. Wagner's brother, Wiltz Wagner, Jr. (born July 7, 1939), of [[Fairhope, Alabama|Fairhope]], [[Alabama]], is a [[Ph.D.]] professor and lung specialist at the [[University of South Alabama]] College of Medicine in [[Mobile, Alabama|Mobile]].{{cite web|url=http://www.usahealthsystem.com/wiltz-w-wagner-jr-phd|title=Wiltz W. Wagner, Jr.|publisher=Usahealthsystem.com|accessdate=August 6, 2018}} {{cite web|url= http://obits.nola.com/obituaries/nola/obituary.aspx?n=helen-bell-wagner&pid=2194312&fhid=2618#sthash.VyGpbhQr.dpuf|title=Helen Bell Wagner|publisher=''[[New Orleans Times-Picayune]]''|accessdate=September 28, 2014}} Wagner attended Isidore Newman School, New Orleans Academy, and [[Tulane University]]. He operated an insurance agency on Carondelet Street in New Orleans.{{cite web|url=https://plus.google.com/118069286344154405269/about?gl=us&hl=en|title=Bryan Wagner Insurance Agency|publisher=plus.google.com|accessdate=September 28, 2014}} In later years, Wagner became heavily involved in [[horse racing]]. He often spent summers in [[Del Mar, California|Del Mar]], [[California]], to be near the famed racetrack. Wagner won the 2009 National Handicapping Championship Tour, as it was then known, and qualified twelve times to the National Horseplayers Championship, during which he earned $101,000. He was part of the NHC since its founding in 1999. For two years, he could not qualify because his wife and the mother of their three children, the former Judy White (born June 9, 1950), sat on the board of directors of the National Thoroughbred Racing Association.{{cite web|url=http://www.drf.com/news/prominent-tournament-player-bryan-wagner-dies|title=Prominent tournament player Bryan Wagner dies|author=Peter Thomas Fornatale|publisher=''[[Daily Racing Form]]''|date=August 1, 2018|accessdate=August 6, 2018}} ==Political life== In the [[nonpartisan blanket primary]] held on April 5, 1980 in District A, Wagner polled 5,513 votes (24.4 percent) and went into the May 17 [[general election]] against [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] Florence W. "Flo" Schornstein (born August 1934), who polled 7,037 (31.2 percent). Five other Democratic candidates received 44.4 percent in the primary. Wagner secured considerable Democratic support and went on to defeat Mrs. Schornstein, 11,900 votes (51.2 percent) to 11,353 ballots (48.8 percent).State of Louisiana, Secretary of State, Special election returns, Orleans Parish, May 17, 1980 The position opened when Frank Friedler retired after serving for six years on the council. Since Wagner's tenure, only a handful of Republicans have been elected to the New Orleans City Council: * [[Peggy Wilson (Louisiana politician)|Peggy Wilson]], an unsuccessful candidate for state insurance commissioner in the 1991 general election, for the [[U.S. Senate]] in 1996, and for [[mayor of New Orleans]] in the 2006 nonpartisan blanket primary.{{cite web|url=http://nutrias.org/inv/council/wilson.htm|title=Biographical Note|publisher=nutrias.org|accessdate=September 29, 2014}} * [[Suzanne Haik Terrell]], council member from 1994 to 2000; the last Louisiana elections commissioner from 2000 to 2004, and the failed Republican candidate for the [[U.S. Senate]] in 2002 against [[Mary Landrieu]] and for [[Attorney General of Louisiana|state attorney general]] against [[Charles Foti]] in 2003. * [[Jay Batt]], with service from 2002 to 2006. Wagner's election to the city council marked a turning point for District A (Lakeview and Uptown), which did not again elect a Democrat until 2006, with the victory of [[Shelley Midura]], who unseated the last Republican in the seat, Jay Batt. “If it hadn’t been for Bryan Wagner, I’m not sure there would be much of a Republican Party in Orleans Parish,” said Batt, the head of the Orleans Parish Republican Executive Committee. Peggy Wilson, who succeeded Wagner in District A, credited Wagner's support for her having been chosen as his successor: "He was very nice to me the whole time that we ran, which was unusual … He sent me flowers the day after the election when I had lost to him [in 1982]. ... He understood politics better than anyone I ever met.”{{cite web|url=https://www.theadvocate.com/new_orleans/news/politics/article_c5322e1c-9449-11e8-bb36-9b9de38b14ef.html|title=Bryan Wagner, first Republican on N.O. City Council since Reconstruction, dies at 75|author=Nicholas Reimann|publisher=''The New Orleans Advocate''|date=July 30, 2018|accessdate=August 6, 2018}} The electoral success of Wilson, Terrell, and Batt benefited from the Republican leanings of District A. Wagner served on numerous municipal boards and commissions, including the Audubon Commission and the board of the [[New Orleans Morial Convention Center]], named for the first [[African-American]] [[mayor of New Orleans]], Democrat [[Ernest Nathan Morial]]. He was said to have worked well with Democrats in developing policy. In 1986, Wagner was named [[Louisiana Republican Party|Republican national committeeman]] for Louisiana to succeed [[Frank Spooner]] of [[Monroe, Louisiana|Monroe]], who stepped down after nine years in the position. Wagner remained active in the state party. He headed the Louisiana delegation to the [[2008 Republican National Convention]] in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota|Minneapolis]], which nominated the [[John McCain|McCain]]-[[Sarah Palin|Palin]] ticket. Spooner was also a delegate to the 2008 convention. In 1996, in supporting [[Bob Dole]] of [[Kansas]] in the unsuccessful race against U.S. President [[Bill Clinton]], Wagner said that the Louisiana GOP should conduct a serious outreach into the black community."Some Louisiana delegates lukewarm about Dole", ''[[Minden Press-Herald]]'', August 13, 1996, p. 1. In 2008, Wagner served as manager for the successful campaign of [[Joseph Cao]] for [[Louisiana's 2nd congressional district]].See the articles on [[Joseph Cao]] and [[William J. Jefferson]]. Cao was subsequently unseated in 2010 by the Democrat [[Cedric Richmond]], who still holds the seat. Upon Wagner's death at the age of seventy-five, Republican [[U.S. Senator]] [[Bill Cassidy]] released a statement: "Bryan was a stalwart leader for our party for fifty years, long before Republicans could even dream of being elected in Orleans Parish. He will be sorely missed, and his many contributions to the cause will make a difference for years to come. Laura and I extend our heartfelt condolences to Bryan’s wife, Judy, and the rest of his family.”{{cite web|url=http://www.kplctv.com/story/38786808/senator-cassidy-releases-statement-on-passing-of-former-nola-councilman|title=Senator Cassidy releases statement on passing of former NOLA councilman|publisher=KPIC-TV|date=August 1, 2018|accessdate=August 3, 2018}} Wagner's memorial service was held on August 6, 2018 at the chapel at Christ Church, 2919 St. Charles Avenue. {{Portalbar|Louisiana|Business and Economics|Politics|Conservatism}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{S-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box |before=Frank Friedler |title=Member of the [[New Orleans City Council]] for District A |years=1980–1986 |after=[[Peggy Wilson (Louisiana politician)|Peggy Wilson]]}} {{end box}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wagner, Bryan}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:New Orleans City Council members]] [[Category:Louisiana Republicans]] [[Category:Businesspeople from New Orleans]] [[Category:Insurance agents]] [[Category:Anglicans]]

The '''chief compliance officer''' ('''CCO''') of a company is the officer primarily responsible for overseeing and managing [[regulatory compliance]] issues within an organization. The CCO typically reports to the [[Chief executive officer|Chief Executive Office]]<nowiki/>r or [[Chief operating officer|Chief Operations Officer]].
The role has long existed at companies that operate in heavily regulated industries such as [[financial services]] and [[healthcare]]. For other companies, the rash of 2000s [[accounting scandals]], the [[Sarbanes-Oxley Act]], and the recommendations of the U.S. Federal Sentencing Guidelines have led to additional CCO appointments.
Scott Cohen, editor and publisher of ''[[Compliance Week]]'', dates the proliferation of CCOs to a 2002 speech by SEC commissioner [[Cynthia Glassman]], in which she called on companies to designate a "corporate responsibility officer."<ref>[https://www.sec.gov/news/speech/spch586.htm SEC Commissioner's Speech: Sarbanes-Oxley and the Idea of "Good" Governance (Cynthia A. Glassman)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The responsibilities of the position often include leading enterprise compliance efforts, designing and implementing internal controls, policies and procedures to assure compliance with applicable local, state and federal laws and regulations and third party guidelines; managing audits and investigations into regulatory and compliance issues; and responding to requests for information from regulatory bodies.

{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox document |document_name=Code of Hammurabi |image=Code-de-Hammurabi-1.jpg |image_width=250px |image_caption= A side view of the [[stele]] "fingertip". |date_created= c. 1754 BC |date_ratified=|writer=[[Hammurabi]] |signers= |purpose=[[Law code]] |wikisource=The Code of Hammurabi }}
The '''Code of Hammurabi''' is a well-preserved [[Babylonia]]n [[code of law]] of ancient [[Mesopotamia]], dated back to about 1754 BC ([[Middle Chronology]]). It is one of the oldest deciphered writings of significant length in the world. The sixth Babylonian king, [[Hammurabi]], enacted the code. A partial copy exists on a 2.25 metre (7.5 ft) stone [[stele]]. It consists of 282 laws, with scaled punishments, adjusting "an [[eye for an eye]], a tooth for a tooth" (''lex talionis'')<ref>{{cite journal|title=Review: The Code of Hammurabi|first= J. Dyneley |last=Prince|journal= The American Journal of Theology |volume= 8| issue = 3 |date=July 1904|pages= 601–609 |publisher=The University of Chicago Press |jstor=3153895}}</ref> as graded depending on social status, of slave versus free, man or woman.<ref name="Bar">[[Gabriele Bartz]], Eberhard König, (Arts and Architecture), Könemann, Köln, (2005), {{ISBN|3-8331-1943-8}}. The laws were based with scaled punishments, adjusting "an eye for an eye" depending on social status.</ref>
Nearly half of the code deals with matters of contract, establishing the wages to be paid to an ox driver or a surgeon for example. Other provisions set the terms of a transaction, the liability of a builder for a house that collapses, or property that is damaged while left in the care of another. A third of the code addresses issues concerning household and family relationships such as inheritance, divorce, paternity, and [[sexual behavior|reproductive behaviour]]. Only one provision appears to impose obligations on an official; this provision establishes that a judge who reaches an incorrect decision is to be fined and removed from the bench permanently.<ref>[http://www.commonlaw.com/Hammurabi.html Code of Hammurabi] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070921205329/http://www.commonlaw.com/Hammurabi.html |date=21 September 2007 }} at commonlaw.com {{cite |url=http://www.commonlaw.com/home/legal-history-and-philosophy/code-of-hammurabi |date=22 May 2017 |title=Code of Hammarubi at Commonlaw }}</ref> A few provisions address issues related to military service.
The code was discovered by modern [[archaeology|archaeologists]] in 1901, and its ''[[editio princeps]]'' translation published in 1902 by [[Jean-Vincent Scheil]]. This nearly complete example of the code is carved into a basalt stele in the shape of a huge [[index finger]],<ref>Iconographic Evidence for Some Mesopotamian Cult Statues, Dominique Collon, Die Welt der Götterbilder, Edited by Groneberg, Brigitte; Spieckermann, Hermann;, and Weiershäuser, Frauke, Berlin, New York (Walter de Gruyter) 2007, pp. 57–84</ref> {{convert|2.25|m|foot|abbr=on}} tall. The code is inscribed in the [[Akkadian language]], using [[cuneiform script]] carved into the stele.
It is currently on display in the [[Louvre]], with replicas in numerous institutions, including the [[University of Chicago Oriental Institute|Oriental Institute at the University of Chicago]], the Northwestern Pritzker School of Law in Chicago, the Clendening History of Medicine Library & Museum at the University of Kansas Medical Center, the library of the [[Theological University of the Reformed Churches]] in the Netherlands, the [[Pergamon Museum]] of Berlin, the Arts Faculty of the University of Leuven in Belgium, the [[National Museum of Iran]] in Tehran, and the Department of Anthropology, [[National Museum of Natural History]], [[Smithsonian Institution]], the University Museum at the University of Pennsylvania, and [[Museum of the Bible]] in Washington, DC.
==History== {{multiple image | align = Middle | image1 = Prologue Hammurabi Code Louvre AO10237.jpg | width1 = 136 | caption1 = The code on clay tablets. | image2 = Code of Hammurabi.jpg | width2 = 136 | caption2 = The code on a basalt stele. | footer = Two versions of the Code at the [[Louvre]]. }} [[Hammurabi]] ruled for nearly 42 years, from about 1792 to 1749 BC according to the [[Middle chronology]]. In the preface to the law, he states, "[[Anu]] and [[Bel (mythology)|Bel]] called by name me, Hammurabi, the exalted prince, who feared God, to bring about the rule of righteousness in the land, to destroy the wicked and the evil-doers; so that the strong should not harm the weak; so that I should rule over the black-headed people like [[Shamash]], and enlighten the land, to further the well-being of mankind."<ref name="wsu">{{cite web|url=http://www.wsu.edu/~dee/MESO/CODE.HTM |title=Mesopotamia: The Code of Hammurabi |accessdate=14 September 2007 |publisher=Washington State University |year=1996 |author1=Edited by Richard Hooker |author2=Translated by L.W King |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070909114038/http://www.wsu.edu/~dee/MESO/CODE.HTM |archivedate=9 September 2007 }}</ref> On the stone slab are 44 columns and 28 paragraphs that contained 282 laws. Some of these laws follow along the rules of "an eye for an eye".<ref>"Hammurabi's Code" {{cite web|url=http://library.thinkquest.org/20176/hammurabis_code.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111101094743/http://library.thinkquest.org/20176/hammurabis_code.htm |archivedate=1 November 2011 |df= }}, Think Quest, retrieved on 2 Nov 2011.</ref>
It had been taken as plunder by the [[Elam|Elamite]] king [[Shutruk-Nahhunte]] in the 12th century BC and was taken to [[Susa]] in [[Elam]] (located in the present-day [[Khuzestan Province]] of Iran) where it was no longer available to the Babylonian people. However, when [[Cyrus the Great]] brought both Babylon and Susa under the rule of his [[Achaemenid Empire|Persian Empire]], and placed copies of the document in the [[Cyrus the Great#Library at Sippar|Library of Sippar]], the text became available for all the peoples of the vast Persian Empire to view.<ref>Marc Van De Mieroop: A History of the Ancient Near East, second edition p. 296</ref>
In 1901, Egyptologist [[Gustave Jéquier]], a member of an expedition headed by [[Jacques de Morgan]], found the stele containing the Code of Hammurabi during archaeological excavations at the ancient site of Susa in Khuzestan.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0H0EpSm8aioC&pg=PA313&lpg=PA313&dq=khuzestan+susa+hammurabi&source=bl&ots=ckH25GVD5y&sig=KJOFs2tnpffmgH_yfQUdZMagTUo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CD0Q6AEwBmoVChMI9KWthsvvyAIVR8FjCh2LZwPw#v=onepage&q=khuzestan%20susa%20hammurabi&f=false|title=Cultures in Contact: From Mesopotamia to the Mediterranean in the Second Millennium B.C|publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]|date=2013|access-date=November 1, 2015}}</ref>
==Laws of Hammurabi's Code== {{Main article|Babylonian law}} The Code of Hammurabi was one of the only sets of laws in the [[ancient Near East]] and also one of the first forms of law.<ref name="yale">{{cite web|url=http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/medieval/hamframe.htm |title=The Code of Hammurabi: Translated by L.W. King |accessdate=14 September 2007 |publisher=Yale University |year=2005 |author=L.W. King |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070916163034/http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/medieval/hamframe.htm |archivedate=16 September 2007 |df= }}</ref> The code of laws was arranged in orderly groups, so that all who read the laws would know what was required of them.<ref>"The Code of Hammurabi: Introduction," [http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/ancient/hamcode.asp], Ancient History Sourcebook, March 1998, retrieved on 2 November 2011.</ref> Earlier collections of laws include the [[Code of Ur-Nammu]], king of [[Ur]] (c. 2050 BC), the [[Laws of Eshnunna]] (c. 1930 BC) and the codex of [[Lipit-Ishtar]] of [[Isin]] (c. 1870 BC), while later ones include the [[Hittite laws]], the [[Assyrian law]]s, and [[Mosaic Law]].<ref>Barton, G.A: ''Archaeology and the Bible''. University of Michigan Library, 2009, (originally published in 1916 by American Sunday-School Union) p. 406.</ref> These codes come from similar cultures in a relatively small geographical area, and they have passages which resemble each other.<ref>Barton 2009, p. 406. Barton, a scientist of Semitic languages at the University of Pennsylvania from 1922 to 1931, stated that while there are similarities between the Mosaic Law and the Code of Hammurabi, a study of the entirety of both laws "convinces the student that the laws of the Old Testament are in no essential way dependent upon the Babylonian laws." He states that "such resemblances" arose from "a similarity of antecedents and of general intellectual outlook" between the two cultures, but that "the striking differences show that there was no direct borrowing."</ref>
[[File:Milkau Oberer Teil der Stele mit dem Text von Hammurapis Gesetzescode 369-2.png|thumb|Figures at the top of the stele "fingernail", above Hammurabi's code of laws.]] The Code of Hammurabi is the longest surviving text from the Old Babylonian period.<ref>"The Code of Hammurabi," [http://www.historyguide.org/ancient/hammurabi.html], The History Guide, 3 August 2009, Retrieved on 2 November 2011.</ref> The code has been seen as an early example of a fundamental law, regulating a government – i.e., a primitive [[constitution]].<ref>What is a Constitution? William David Thomas, Gareth Stevens (2008) p. 8</ref><ref>Flach, Jacques. Le Code de Hammourabi et la constitution originaire de la propriete dans l'ancienne Chaldee. (Revue historique. Paris, 1907. 8. v. 94, pp. 272–289.</ref> The code is also one of the earliest examples of the idea of [[presumption of innocence]], and it also suggests that both the accused and accuser have the opportunity to provide [[evidence]].<ref>Victimology: Theories and Applications, Ann Wolbert Burgess, Albert R. Roberts, Cheryl Regehr, Jones & Bartlett Learning, 2009, p. 103</ref> The occasional nature of many provisions suggests that the code may be better understood as a codification of Hammurabi's supplementary judicial decisions, and that, by memorializing his wisdom and justice, its purpose may have been the self-glorification of Hammurabi rather than a modern legal code or constitution. However, its copying in subsequent generations indicates that it was used as a model of legal and judicial reasoning.<ref>For this alternative interpretation see Jean Bottéro, "The 'Code' of Hammurabi" in ''Mesopotamia: Writing, Reasoning and the Gods'' (University of Chicago, 1992), pp. 156–184.</ref>
While the Code of Hammurabi was trying to achieve equality, biases still existed towards those categorized in the lower end of the social spectrum and some of the punishments and justice could be gruesome. The magnitude of criminal penalties often was based on the identity and gender of both the person committing the crime and the victim. The Code issues justice following the three classes of Babylonian society: property owners, freed men, and slaves.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.history.com/news/history-lists/8-things-you-may-not-know-about-hammurabis-code|title=8 Things You May Not Know About Hammurabi’s Code|work=History.com|access-date=2017-09-07}}</ref>
Punishments for someone assaulting someone from a lower class were far lighter than if they had assaulted someone of equal or higher status.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.history.com/news/history-lists/8-things-you-may-not-know-about-hammurabis-code|title=8 Things You May Not Know About Hammurabi’s Code|work=History.com|access-date=2017-09-07}}</ref> For example, if a doctor killed a rich patient, he would have his hands cut off, but if he killed a slave, only financial restitution was required.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyextra.com/article/international-history/nutshell-babylon|title=What was Babylon? |work=History Extra}}</ref> Women could also receive punishments that their male counterparts would not, as men were permitted to have affairs with their servants and slaves, whereas married women would be harshly punished for committing adultery.<ref name=":0" />
==Other copies== [[File:Hammurabi stele amnh ny.JPG|thumb|The Hammurabi stele at the [[American Museum of Natural History]], New York.]] [[File:Hammurabi code Istanbul.jpg|thumb|A version of the code at the [[Istanbul Archaeological Museums]].]] Various copies of portions of the Code of Hammurabi have been found on baked clay tablets, some possibly older than the celebrated basalt stele now in the Louvre. The Prologue of the Code of Hammurabi (the first 305 inscribed squares on the stele) is on such a tablet, also at the Louvre (Inv #AO 10237). Some gaps in the list of benefits bestowed on cities recently annexed by Hammurabi may imply that it is older than the famous stele (currently dated to the early 18th century BC).<ref>Fant, Clyde E. and Mitchell G. Reddish (2008), [https://books.google.com/books?id=Dj6zVQJz7zYC&pg=PA62&lpg=PA62&dq=%22Code+of+Hammurabi%22+AND+2358&source=bl&ots=h-WEMEm_S7&sig=otruVc43aRR7ge-2v-78tcMQih8&hl=en&ei=tU1iSrvWNdmOtgfjr9EC&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3 ''Lost Treasures of the Bible: Understanding the Bible Through Archaeological Artifacts in World Museums''], Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Co., p. 62.</ref> Likewise, the [[Museum of the Ancient Orient]], part of the [[Istanbul Archaeology Museums]], also has a "Code of Hammurabi" clay tablet, dated to 1790 BC, in (Room 5, Inv # Ni 2358).<ref>[[John Freely|Freely, John]], ''Blue Guide Istanbul'' (5th ed., 2000), London: [[A&C Black]], New York: [[WW Norton]], p. 121. ("The most historic of the inscriptions here [i.e., Room 5, Museum of the Ancient Orient, Istanbul] is the famous Code of Hammurabi (#Ni 2358) dated 1750 BCE, the world's oldest recorded set of laws.")</ref><ref>[http://english.istanbul.gov.tr/Default.aspx?pid=13150 Museum of the Ancient Orient website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503212551/http://english.istanbul.gov.tr/Default.aspx?pid=13150 |date=3 May 2012 }} ("This museum contains a rich collection of ancient ... archaeological finds, including ... seals from Nippur and a copy of the Code of Hammurabi.")</ref>
In July 2010, archaeologists reported that a fragmentary Akkadian cuneiform tablet was discovered at [[Tel Hazor]], [[Israel]], containing a c. 1700 BC text that was said to be partly parallel to portions of the Hammurabi code. The Hazor law code fragments are currently being prepared for publication by a team from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/138788|title=Code of Hammurabi Tablet Found |work=Inside Israel News – Arutz Sheva}}</ref>
==Laws covered== {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage = [[File:P1050763 Louvre code Hammurabi face rwk.JPG|210px]] | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_w5NGOHbgTw Law Code Stele of King Hammurabi, 1792–1750 BC], [[Smarthistory]] }} The laws covered such subjects as:
; Slander : Ex. Law #127: "If any one "point the finger" at a sister of a god or the wife of any one, and can not prove it, this man shall be taken before the judges and his brow shall be marked (by cutting the skin, or perhaps hair)."<ref name=Code>{{cite web|title=The Code of Hammurabi|website= Internet Sacred Text Archive|publisher= Evinity Publishing |year=2011|accessdate=November 17, 2013|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/ane/ham/ham06.htm}}</ref> ; Trade : Ex. Law #265: "If a herdsman, to whose care cattle or sheep have been entrusted, be guilty of fraud and make false returns of the natural increase, or sell them for money, then shall he be convicted and pay the owner ten times the loss."<ref name=Code/> ; Slavery and status of slaves as property : Ex. Law #15: "If any one take a male or female slave of the court, or a male or female slave of a freed man, outside the city gates, he shall be put to death."<ref name=Code/> ; The duties of workers : Ex. Law #42: "If any one take over a field to till it, and obtain no harvest therefrom, it must be proved that he did no work on the field, and he must deliver grain, just as his neighbor raised, to the owner of the field."<ref name=Code/> ; Theft : Ex. Law #22: "If any one is committing a robbery and is caught, then he shall be put to death."<ref name=Code/> ; Trade : Ex. Law #104: "If a merchant give an agent corn, wool, oil, or any other goods to transport, the agent shall give a receipt for the amount, and compensate the merchant therefor. Then he shall obtain a receipt from the merchant for the money that he gives the merchant."<ref name=Code/> ;Liability : Ex. Law #53: "If any one be too lazy to keep his dam in proper condition, and does not so keep it; if then the dam break and all the fields be flooded, then shall he in whose dam the break occurred be sold for money, and the money shall replace the corn which he has caused to be ruined."<ref name=Code/> ;Divorce : Ex. Law #142: "If a woman quarrel with her husband, and say: "You are not congenial to me," the reasons for her prejudice must be presented. If she is guiltless, and there is no fault on her part, but he leaves and neglects her, then no guilt attaches to this woman, she shall take her dowry and go back to her father's house."<ref name=Code/> One of the best known laws from Hammurabi's code was: : Ex. Law #196: "If a man destroy the eye of another man, they shall destroy his eye. If one break a man's bone, they shall break his bone. If one destroy the eye of a freeman or break the bone of a freeman he shall pay one gold [[Mina (unit)|mina]]. If one destroy the eye of a man's slave or break a bone of a man's slave he shall pay one-half his price."<ref name=Code/>
Hammurabi had many other punishments, as well. If a son strikes his father, his hands shall be hewn off. Translations vary.<ref name="king translation">Translated by L.W. King, Hammurabi's Code of Laws, [http://eawc.evansville.edu/anthology/hammurabi.htm ''Hammurabi's Code of Laws''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509192326/http://eawc.evansville.edu/anthology/hammurabi.htm |date=9 May 2008 }}</ref><ref name="harper translation">Translated by L.W. King, Hammurabi's Code of Laws, [//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4e/The_code_of_Hammurabi.pdf The Code of Hammurabi King of Babylon] by Robert Francis Harper (PDF)</ref>
'''Adultery'''
Ex. Law # 129: "If the wife of a man has been caught lying with another man, they shall bind them and throw them into the waters. If the owner of the wife would save his wife then in turn the king could save his servant."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Western Civilization Volume 1: From the Origins of Civilization to the Age of Absolutism|last=C. Sax|first=Benjamin|publisher=Greenhaven Press|year=2001|isbn=1-56510-988-0|location=San Diego|page=35}}</ref>

page.title: Comparison chart of civic technology platforms

revision.text:
[[Civic technology]] is defined as technology that enables engagement, participation or enhances the relationship between the people and government by enhancing citizen communications and public decision, improving government delivery of service, and infrastructure. Civic technology platforms specifically designed to improve citizen participation in governance. We distinguished civic tech from government technology. Government technology being technology that directly deals with government infrastructure.
== Platform types ==
We used the categorization on democratic innovations according to Dr. Graham Smith of the [[University of Southampton]], in his book "Beyond the Ballot":<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://westminsterresearch.wmin.ac.uk/11541/|title=Beyond the ballot: 57 democratic innovations from around the world|last=Smith|first=Graham|date=2005|website=westminsterresearch.wmin.ac.uk|publisher=POWER Inquiry|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
* Electoral innovations - "aim to increase electoral turnout" * Consultation innovations - "aim to inform decision-makers of citizens’ views" * Deliberative innovations - "aim to bring citizens together to deliberate on policy issues, the outcomes of which may influence decision-makers" * Co-governance innovations - "aim to give citizens significant influence during the process of decision-making" * Direct democracy innovations - "aim to give citizens final decision-making power on key issues" * E-democracy innovations - "use information technology to engage citizens in the decision-making process"
